1. The thought of bloating - if one contemplates a dead body,
Swollen like a leather bag filled with wind.
Different from its original appearance.
This is called the thought of bloating.
2. The thought of bluish-black - if one contemplates a dead body,
The skin and flesh turn yellow, red, and black, with a bluish-black color.
This is called the thought of bluish-black.
3. The thought of decay - if one contemplates a dead body,
Blown by the wind and exposed to the sun,
It becomes bloated and bursts open, scattered on the ground.
This is called the thought of decay.
4. The thought of blood-smeared - if one contemplates a dead body,
Blood and pus flow out from all over the body,
Soiled and smeared.
This is called the thought of blood-smeared.
5. The thought of pus and rot - if one contemplates a dead body,
Maggots and pus flow out,
The skin and flesh decay and rot,
Poured out on the ground.
This is called the thought of pus and rot.
Sixth, the thought of being eaten. If one contemplates a dead body,
being eaten by worms and maggots,
birds pecking out its eyes,ğŸ”½foxes and dogs gnawing at it,
and tigers and wolves tearing it apart, this is the thought of being eaten.
Seventh, the thought of scattering. If one contemplates a dead body,
torn apart by birds and beasts,
the body's form scattered,
muscles severed, bones separated, head and limbs strewn about,
this is the thought of scattering.
Eighth, the thought of bones. If one contemplates a dead body,
the skin and flesh already gone,
only seeing white bones,
connected by sinews or scattered and strewn about,
like shells or conches,
this is the thought of bones.
Ninth, the thought of burning. If one contemplates a dead body being burned by fire,
exploding with smoke and stench,
the firewood exhausted, the form extinguished,
like ashes and soil,
even if not burned,
it will still return to destruction.
This is the thought of burning.

fear is immediately removed.

is another name for the mind retaining and recollecting.
Concentrating the mind on the eight kinds of merits,
it is called the eight remembrances.
Not only can it remove worldly fears,
if one can cultivate well,
it can also remove all obstacles and difficulties in the three realms of worldly birth and death.

The precepts shared with concentration can prevent the evil thoughts of afflictions.

One attains liberation through wisdom.
This is called mindfulness of precepts.
Fifth, mindfulness of giving up. Mindfulness of giving up means
there are two kinds.
First, giving up of giving.
Second, giving up of abandoning afflictions.
Giving up of giving
can give rise to great merit.
Giving up of abandoning afflictions
based on this, one attains wisdom and enters nirvana.
This is called mindfulness of giving up.
Sixth, mindfulness of the heavens. Mindfulness of the heavens means
the four heavenly kings,
up to the heaven of freely partaking of others' enjoyments.
There are also four kinds of heavens.
First, named heavens, second, born heavens, third, pure heavens, fourth, born pure heavens.
Such fruits and retributions are pure.
Benefiting all.
This is called mindfulness of the heavens.
Seventh, mindfulness of Ä€nÄpÄna.
Mindfulness of Ä€nÄpÄna is as explained in the sixteen special qualities.
Mindfulness of inhalation and exhalation. When practicing mindfulness in this way,

Eighth, mindfulness of death. Mindfulness of death

The first gate of the ten contemplations, the second chapter on the ten contemplations: first, the contemplation of impermanence; second, the contemplation of suffering; third, the contemplation of non-self; fourth, the contemplation of the impurity of food; fifth, the contemplation of the unsatisfactoriness of the world; sixth, the contemplation of death; seventh, the contemplation of impurity; eighth, the contemplation of cessation; ninth, the contemplation of separation; tenth, the contemplation of exhaustion. The ten contemplations are explained after the eight mindfulnesses.
The MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ ÅšÄstra says:
The nine perceptions are like binding a thief, and the ten perceptions are like killing a thief.
If so, then it should be explained immediately after the nine perceptions.
But when cultivating the nine perceptions,
there are obstacles such as fear and terror.
Therefore, the eight mindfulnesses are explained.
Having become free from all fear and terror,
the mind is at ease without obstacles.
Therefore, the ten perceptions are explained next.
Generally speaking, the term perception means
being able to transform the mind and transform perceptions.
Being able to transform the perceptions of permanence, bliss, and so forth,
and all the inverted views and so forth,
is called perception.
The first three perceptions are explained for the sake of severing the delusions of views.
The middle four perceptions are explained for the sake of severing the delusions of thought.
The last three perceptions are explained for the sake of those cultivating the path of no-more-learning.
Therefore,
a person of decaying Dharma,
cultivating these ten perceptions,
is able to sever the bonds of the three realms
and realize the holy fruit of no-outflows.
First, the perception of impermanence - contemplating all conditioned dharmas as impermanent,
the perception that accords with wisdom
is called the perception of impermanence.
All conditioned dharmas are of two kinds.
First, sentient beings.
Second, the environment.
These two are newly arising and perishing.
Therefore, they are impermanent.
Second, the thought of suffering - contemplating all conditioned dharmas as suffering.
The thought associated with wisdom.
Is called the thought of suffering.
If conditioned dharmas are impermanent,
They are then suffering, constantly changing and oppressed by the three sufferings and eight sufferings.
Therefore, it is called suffering.
Third, the thought of no-self - contemplating all dharmas as equal and without self.
The thought associated with wisdom.
Is called the thought of no-self.
If conditioned dharmas are all suffering, then they are without self.
Because there is no independence.
Also, because suffering arises from conditions and has no inherent nature.
In that which has no inherent nature,
The self cannot be found.
Fourth, the thought of food as impure - contemplating food as impure.
The thought associated with wisdom.
Is called the thought of food as impure.
The food and drink of the world,
All arise from impure causes and conditions.
Therefore, there is flesh that grows from semen, blood, and the birth canal, like curds and butter.
All should be observed according to the situation.
They are all impure.
Fifth, the thought of the world being unenjoyable - observing that the entire world is unenjoyable.
The thought associated with wisdom.
Is called the thought of the world being unenjoyable.
There are two kinds of worlds.
One is sentient beings.
The other is the country.
There are faults and evils, nothing enjoyable.
Sixth, the thought of death - observing the wisdom of death, the thought associated with wisdom.
Is called the thought of death.
If in one lifetime of karmic retribution,
One is always pursued by two kinds of death,
Then the out-breath does not repay the in-breath.
Seventh, the thought of impurity - observing the impurity of one's own and others' bodies.
The thought associated with wisdom.
Is called the thought of impurity.
If one observes that this body contains thirty-six substances,
On the outside there are nine orifices,
With foul discharge constantly flowing.
From birth to death,
there is not a single pure thing.
8. The thought of cutting off - contemplating nirvana as separate from birth and death.
The thought associated with wisdom,
is called the thought of cutting off.
The practitioner contemplates,
if nirvana is pure,
without afflictions,
one should sever the bonds and realize nirvana.
9. The thought of separation - contemplating nirvana as separate from birth and death.
The thought associated with wisdom,
is called the thought of separation.
The practitioner contemplates,
if nirvana is pure,
separated from birth and death,
one should separate from birth and death and realize nirvana.
10. The thought of exhaustion - contemplating the exhaustion of bonds and birth and death in nirvana.
The thought associated with wisdom,
is called the thought of exhaustion.
The practitioner contemplates,
if nirvana is pure,
the bonds and birth and death,
if the bonds have not yet been exhausted,
and the karma of birth and death,
realize nirvana.

The fifth liberation is the sphere of infinite consciousness. 6. The sixth liberation is the sphere of nothingness. 7. The seventh liberation is the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception. 8. The eighth liberation is the cessation of perception and feeling. The first nine and ten perceptions,

trains in the various concentrations,
when one attains the holy fruit,

Therefore, it is called recluseship.
If one gives rise to true, uncontaminated wisdom,

1. Having the appearance of form internally, observing form externally. Having the appearance of form internally meansğŸ”½not destroying internal form,

Fourth, the liberation of the sphere of infinite space - if one extinguishes the form of the fundamental four dhyÄnas,
and the three liberations and four bases of supernatural power,

unifying the mind and relying on the boundless space to enter concentration, one then contemplates this concentration based on the aggregates, sense bases, and elements.
Therefore, there is impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and no-self, which are false and unreal.
The mind gives rise to disgust and turns away from them.
But one does not become attached to them.
One deeply enters and does not turn back.
This is called the liberation of the sphere of infinite space.
Fifth, the liberation of the sphere of consciousness - if one abandons space,
unifies the mind, and relies on consciousness to enter concentration,
one then contemplates this concentration.
Based on the aggregates, sense bases, and elements,
there is impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and no-self.
It is false and unreal.
The mind gives rise to disgust and turns away from them.
But one does not become attached to them.
One deeply enters and does not turn back.
This is called the liberation of the sphere of consciousness.
Sixth, the renunciation of the sphere of nothingness. If one renounces consciousness,
and single-mindedly contemplates the sphere of nothingness to enter concentration,
one immediately observes this concentration,
based on the aggregates, sense bases, and elements.
Therefore, it has impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and no-self.
It is false and unreal.
The mind gives rise to aversion and does not become attached.
One deeply enters and does not turn back.
This is the renunciation of the sphere of nothingness.
Seventh, the renunciation of the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception. If one renounces the sphere of nothingness,
and single-mindedly contemplates the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception to enter concentration,
one immediately observes this concentration,
based on the aggregates, sense bases, and elements.
Therefore, it has impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and no-self.
It is false and unreal.
The mind gives rise to aversion and does not become attached.
One deeply enters and does not turn back.
This is the renunciation of the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception.
Eighth, the renunciation of the cessation of perception and feeling. One renounces the cessation of perception and feeling, and all mental activities.

The disciples of the Buddhas
are troubled and disgusted with a scattered mind.
They wish to enter concentration and rest.
Using the Dharma of nirvana,
they peacefully place it within the body.
Therefore, it is called the extinction of perception and feeling while physically realizing.

The six supernatural powers: the first is the divine eye; the second is the divine ear; the third is knowing the minds of others; the fourth is knowing past lives; the fifth is the spiritual powers of the body; the sixth is the extinction of contaminations. The six supernatural powers are discussed after transformations.
There are three different meanings.
If it is the supernatural powers obtained through retribution,
one can only attain transformations after attaining the supernatural powers.
If it is the supernatural powers attained through cultivation,
one first cultivates transformations
and then attains the supernatural powers.
Now, since this is about the sequence of attainment through cultivation,
therefore, after transformation, it discusses spiritual powers.
All of these are called spiritual powers.
The Sutra of the Adornment of the Sage's Merits says:
Spirit means the mind of heaven.
Power means the nature of wisdom.
The wisdom of heaven
penetrates and illuminates without obstruction.
Therefore, it is called spiritual power.
1. The spiritual power of the heavenly eye. Cultivating the heavenly eye,
if one gives rise to the pure form of the four elements of the form realm in deep meditation, and abides in the eye faculty,
one can then see the sentient beings of the six realms dying here and being born there,
and see all the various forms and colors in the world.
This is the spiritual power of the heavenly eye.
2. The spiritual power of the heavenly ear. Cultivating the heavenly ear,
if one gives rise to the pure form of the four elements of the form realm in deep meditation, and abides in the ear faculty,
one can then hear the languages of the sentient beings of the six realms,
and the various sounds in the world.
This is the spiritual power of the heavenly ear.
Third, the supernormal knowledge of knowing others' minds. Those who cultivate the knowledge of others' minds,
if in deep meditation,
give rise to the knowledge of others' minds,
they can know the minds and mental factors of sentient beings in the six realms,
and the various objects of their thoughts.
This is the supernormal knowledge of knowing others' minds.
Fourth, the supernormal knowledge of past lives. Those who cultivate the supernormal knowledge of past lives,
if in deep meditation,
give rise to the knowledge of past lives,
they can know their own past lives in one, two, a hundred thousand, or even eighty thousand great eons,
and the events that occurred.
They can also know the past lives of sentient beings in the six realms,
and the deeds they have done.
This is the knowledge of past lives.
Fifth, the supernormal power of the body. Those who cultivate the supernormal power of the body,
if in deep meditation they attain the supernormal power of the body,
there are two kinds of supernormal power.
First, flying swiftly without obstruction by mountains or barriers.
Second, being able to transform one's own body, others' bodies,
and all that exists in the world.
One can do as one wishes.
This is the spiritual power of mental freedom.
